Description: The unique identifier (primary key) for the specimen record. This field should be used to store the barcode or the accession number (herbaria only). This field is enforced to be unique per collection.

Any other identifier for a specimen record that is not the catalog number. This field is typically used to store the old catalog number for collections that are in the process of switching from one cataloging system to another (e.g. barcode system).
The name of the person who collected the specimen or made the observation.
Other collectors that were present at the time of collection
Darwin Core field(s): This field is not defined by the Darwin Core standard, which places primary and secondary collectors concatenated the recordedBy field.

Description: The collection number assigned to the specimen by the collector.

The date the specimen was collected. While dates can be entered using your preferred format, the value will be converted and stored as an ISO-8601 numeric format (YYYY-MM-DD). Note that unknown month and days can be entered as “00”. For example, a collection with a date of “March 1956” can be entered as “1956-03-00”.
Can be used to record date exactly as entered on label. Particularly useful for non-standard date formats or date ranges.
The numeric value of the year, month, and day at the time of collection. These fields are automatically populated when the date is entered.
A range of collection dates can be represented here as numeric day of year values. These values will be automatically calculated if you enter a date range in the verbatim date field
The Latin name of the specimen without the author. Could be anything from kingdom down to subspecies or variety, depending on the level of the identification.
Example(s): Pinaceae, Pinus, Pinus edulis, Pinus edulis var. fallax

Description: The name of the person who first named the taxon. This field autofills after entering the scientific name as long as that taxon is in the taxonomic thesaurus.
The determiner’s expression of uncertainty in their identification. This will be listed on the label along with the scientific name.
The family to which the taxa belongs. This field autofills after entering the scientific name as long as the taxon exists in the taxonomic thesaurus.
The name of the person who identified the specimen. Also called a determiner.
The date the identification was made. Date can be entered as free form text and do not need to be in a standard date format.
The reference source used to make the identification.
Example(s): Nesom, Guy L. 2006. Flora of North America – Asteraceae. vol. 20

Description: Any additional notes regarding the identification of the specimen.
Any additional notes regarding the taxonomic name to which the specimen was identify.
The name of the country in which the specimen was collected. To aid data entry, a drop down menu will appear as one types, though names outside of the list can still be entered.
The name of the state or province in which the specimen was collected. As one types, a selection list will appear for the given country.

The name of the county in which the specimen was collected. Choose one from the drop down menu. For specimens collected outside of the United States, enter the next geographic region below state/province.
The name of the municipality in which the specimen was collected. For specimens collected outside of the United States, enter the 4th level geographic designation.
The detailed location in which the specimen was collected.
Example(s): 9.5 miles NW of Sedona along Boynton Pass Rd.

Description: Comments or notes about the Location.
An identifier for the set of location information (data associated with dcterms:Location). May be a global unique identifier or an identifier specific to the data set.

Checking the Locality Security checkbox will hide images and locality details below the level of county from unauthorized users. For more information about locality security in Symbiota, visit our Redacting Data page.
Darwin Core field(s): This field is not defined by the Darwin Core standard.

Description: The geographic latitude and longitude in decimal degrees. Latitudes from the southern hemisphere and longitudes in the western hemisphere (e.g. USA) should be entered as negative values. Click on the “Tools” button to enter the coordinates in the degree, minute, seconds (DMS) or the UTM formats. Decimal degrees are the preferred coordinate standard as defined by Darwin Core.

The accuracy of the georeference coordinates in meters (numeric value only). This is measured as the radius of a circle where the true point would be found if known. Protocols for assigning error radii to georeference points can be found in this Georeference Quick Reference Guide.
The geographic system that was used to get the coordinates. This field autofills when using GeoLocate or the Google Maps tool for georeferencing.

If the coordinates recorded on the specimen label are in a format other than decimal degrees, enter them here. Click the F (format) button to enter non-decimal formats (e.g., UTMs, degrees/minutes/seconds) and click Insert Coordinates. This will place the original format in Verbatim Coordinates and will auto-convert to decimal degrees in the Latitude and Longitude fields if these fields are blank. Click the “«” symbol to replace existing decimal values.
The elevation in meters at which the specimen was collected. Also called altitude. Use only the left field with the right field blank when a single elevation exists.

The verbatim elevation at which the specimen was collected. This is typically used to record an elevation measurement that was recorded in feet or an uncertainty designation. When the elevation in meters field is left blank, the value will automatically be converted to meters if you press Tab after entering a value in this field. Click the “«” symbol to replace the previously entered meters values.
The range of depth below the local surface, in meters.
The original verbatim description of the depth below the local surface at which the specimen was collected.
The name of the person who georeferenced the specimen record. This field autofills when using GeoLocate for georeferencing.
The source of the standards used to georeference.
Example(s): Georeferencing Quick Guide. Zermoglio et al. 2020

Description: The tool or tools used to georeference.
Indicates whether or not the georeference has been reviewed or verified.
Any additional notes regarding the georeferencing of the specimen.
The description of the habitat in which the specimen was collected.
Example(s): Wet areas along a small stream in chaparral, roadside

Description: The substrate on which the specimen was collected. Mostly used for lichen and bryophyte specimens.
Darwin Core field(s): Darwin Core lumps this information into habitat.

Description: A list of the names of other species occurring with the collected specimen.
Example(s): Quercus, Arctostaphylos, Ceanothus, Rhus, Eriogonum, Salvia

Description: A physical description of the specimen at the time of collection. This often includes information that can be lost or difficult to observe after the collection and preservation process.
Darwin Core field(s): In a Darwin Core export, this is concatenated with occurrenceRemarks

Description: Any additional notes regarding the specimen. This field often includes characteristics of the population, such as its frequency or rarity.
A list of additional measurements, facts, characteristics, or assertions about the specimen in a format that allows programmatic parsing of the data
The age or stage of the organism at the time of collection/observation. Typically used for zoological collections.
The biological sex of the occurrence.
The number of individuals in the occurrence
The names and references to methods used to collect or sample an occurrence
Example(s): UV light trap, mist net, Takats et al. 2001. Guidelines for Nocturnal Owl Monitoring in North America. Beaverhill Bird Observatory and Bird Studies Canada, Edmonton, Alberta. 32 pp., http://www.bsc-eoc.org/download/Owl.pdf

Description: Preparation or preservation method for a specimen
The reproductive stage the specimen is in. Typically used for plant and fungal collections.
The state of establishment at the time of collection.
Check when the organism was established with the aid of humans and would not be able to exist on their own. This true/false field enables the ability to filter non-native or naturalized species.
Darwin Core field(s): Not currently exported in DwC format, but see degreeOfEstablishment

Description: The type designation of a specimen, if it is a type specimen
The location or status of the physical specimen.
This is the Global Unique Identification (GUID) for the specimen. This identification code should be stable and uniquely identify the specimen relative to all other specimens within the world.
N/A
The acronym of the owning institution. Only enter a value if the owning institution is different than what was entered when the metadata for the collection institution was added to the portal.

The type of record the specimen is classified as. For physical collections, this field defaults to “PreservedSpecimen” (aka herbarium specimen) and for observation projects, the default is “Observation”.
The language of the label information.
The status of the digital record. This field is used for internal data management and review. The values used are dictated by the specific workflow of each institution.
Used for printing labels. You can create a label project and print that set of labels after you’ve entered the data.
The number of duplicate specimens created. This will dictate the number of labels printed for specimen.
The longest geologic time intervals.
A subdivision of an eon that is a shorter interval of geologic time.
A subdivision of an era that is a shorter interval of geologic time.
Example(s): Ordovician, Silurian, Devonian, Carboniferous, Mississippian, Pennsylvanian, Permian, Triassic, Jurassic, Cretaceous, Paleogene, Neogene, Quaternary.

Description: A subdivision of a period that is a shorter interval of geologic time. The Epoch field is currently being recorded using Series, the chronostratigraphic units.
The chronostratigraphic term given to the succession of rock strata laid down in a single geochronologic age.
A local name for a stage that was applied to this specimen.

Name of the earliest possible geochronologic eon, era, period, epoch or age, or the lowest chronostratigraphic eonothem, erathem, system, series, or stage attributable to the stratigraphic horizon from which the cataloged specimen was collected.

Name of the latest possible geochronologic eon, era, period, epoch or age, or the highest chronostratigraphic eonothem, erathem, system, series or stage attributable to the stratigraphic horizon from which the cataloged specimen was collected.
Age of specimen/rock in years determined using radioactive decay of isotopes (Carbon-14, argon-argon, potassium-argon, uranium-lead, etc.) and other quantitative dating methods.
Field for institutions that arrange collections by geologic time or biostratigraphy. The physical location of a specimen within the collection space.
Name given to collections of fossils of the same age from a single locality or multiple localities within a specific geographic area.
Example(s): Chalk Bluffs, Stewart Valley, Bridge Creek, Mazon Creek

Description: The name of the lowest possible geological biostratigraphic zone of the stratigraphic horizon from which the cataloged item was collected.
The name of the lithostratigraphic group from which the cataloged specimen was collected.
Example(s): Bathurst, Lower Wealden, Monte Cristo, Contra Costa, Panoche

Description: The name of the lithostratigraphic formation from which the cataloged specimen was collected. The National Geologic Map Database Geolex Search is a great resource for the named lithostratigraphic units accepted by the USGS.
Related Documentation: National Geologic Map Database Geolex Search: https://ngmdb.usgs.gov/Geolex/search
Example(s): Notch Peak, House Limestone, Fillmore, Chinle

Description: The name of the lithostratigraphic member from which the cataloged item was collected.
Example(s): Lava Dam, Hellnmaria, Brown Mountain Sandstone

Description: The name of the lithostratigraphic bed from which the cataloged item was collected.
The depositional environment of the rock unit from which cataloged specimen was collected.
Field for terms to describe the types of rock/sediment from which the cataloged specimen was collected.
Field to record additional details about the geology, stratigraphy, more detailed lithology description, palynological sampling info, core data, etc.
Field to record type of plant organ cataloged specimen represents.
Example(s): stem, strobilus, sterile leaf, fertile leaf, pinnule(s), rooting organ, rootlet, megasporangium, sporangium, spore, sterile axis, fertile axis, root

Description: Field to record types of prepared slides of specimens, noting the type of preparation and mounting medium, and to provide England Finder coordinates for palynomorph slides.

An identifier for the set of information associated with a GeologicalContext (the location within a geological context, such as stratigraphy). May be a global unique identifier or an identifier specific to the data set.
